text.text_bit: Yes.  But this part was a long building, and it was cut and, you know, made extra rooms.  I don’t know whether, if I was ever in it after they fixed it up.  I don’t know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But when you went to it, it was just the center part?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, it was just the small center part.  Well, I helped babies in there some, teach some of the little ones some when he was there.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Tell me about that.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That’s a long time ago!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: No, tell me about your teaching.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I taught the first and second grade then.  They were in this little room here, I remember that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: On the right?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  And they had this room added on, you know, so they could have more classrooms, because when I went there, they didn’t have but one big, long room.  And they got—these were added on after my children went to school.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, tell me how you—Describe a day at school when you were teaching.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I had some little old brats!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did you really?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes!  Like David Harris and Lorraine and—I don’t know who all I had.  Yeah, I had the Watts, Pete Watts’s, ah, grandma; I had Jimmy Watts;

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I had him and some of Vera’s children, her oldest girl; and a bunch of them, all about Floyd’s, you know, about Floyd’s age.  Dewey wasn’t born yet, that’s right.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: This was just after you got married?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, this was just about five—Floyd was going to school then.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So, you were married about five years?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: About six years.  Seven.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, what time did you have to show up?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: In the morning.  I fill in half a day with them and then I’d come home, and helped teach those little kids.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How did you do it?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, helped them teach their reading and spelling, things like that.  Most of them had arithmetic, you know, and, you see, I’d get them off; and then he wouldn’t have to worry about them so much in the afternoon.  They’d get off, and then he’d have time to put in with the bigger classes, you see?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes.  So they had one teacher?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And he was--?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Davis.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Davis.  And he taught all the classes?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So, what happened when you went home at noon?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, you see, I’d get the worst of it over, and he’d just, you know, just have them—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He’d just look in on them?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Were they bad?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: David was! [Laughs]  Oh, he couldn’t be still!  He was messing around all the time!  Is this Nettie Owl and her family? [Points to photo]  That has to be Charlotte!  And that’s Lula.  And this undoubtedly had to be Frell over here.  Is it, or not?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I don’t know.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And that’s Tom right there.  Tom died just a few years ago.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: About a year ago?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: A year ago.  You—I never seen Tom since I went.  He was down here, but I didn’t get to see him.  I hated I didn’t get to see him since he growed up.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Since school?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: My goodness.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And I hated that I didn’t get to see him when he was at Doris’s, but he was just going through, you know.  I talked to him and I said, “I’d like to see you, Tom.”  And he said, “I would, too, but we are leaving tomorrow.”  And they had that, you know, trip planned, and I didn’t get to see him.  I hated that so bad!  Doris was the one who called and told me he was there, so I told her, “Let me talk to him a little bit.”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: So I talked to him.  And that’s Henry there.  And this is David.  And I’m pretty sure this is Frell.  And this is probably, is—that must be George there.  That’s George, Henry, and Thomas, and that’s Frell, and that’s David.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That’s a handsome family.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They are.  They were all good-looking boys, every one of them.  And Lula was good-looking when she was young.  And that’s Henry Owl.  And that, I guess—is that her, Nettie’s, kid there?  The baby?  Or is that Lula’s?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I don’t know.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I bet that’s Lula’s.  After Lula had her first one—she had a younger one, called Mable, I believe; but she died, and she’s buried over here at the reservation.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Who?  Lula’s?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, Nettie’s.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh.  Nettie lived here for a time?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  She had her baby here after she—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: With Loyd?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  She was living here with Loyd.  She lived down there.  She lived at Cherokee with Loyd Owl, and then after she left Loyd, you know, she came back to the reservation and stayed there.  And she married Bobby Harris and she lived there until--.  And the reason she was in Cherokee, they took her there to the hospital, you know, for the doctors, you know.  And she didn’t get well and come home.  And she died.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, how come her baby is buried here on the reservation?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, she lived here.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: With Loyd?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  When she left, she brought her family with her, you know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, and the baby died here.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She had one that wasn’t in school?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That one time, you know.  [Looks at photo]  That’s Sister Helen.  Is that taken in a—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That’s at the Gambaro.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That’s where I thought it was!  And that’s a good picture of Helen.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It really is!  And that is Miss Alberta.

text.speaker: NOTE
text.text_bit: [Break in tape]

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You were teaching in there.  How long did you do that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: For one session.  I helped him, you know, because he had so many students, you know.  And he wanted somebody to just come and help him.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did your mother ever help out in the school?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It must have been Rosa.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Rosie did.  Rosie taught school down there.  The whole thing.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, she kept the school?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, and I think she taught for two or three years down there.  Doris can tell you about that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She can tell me more about that.  Okay, so then when did Samuel move in there?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, that was after the school was—they made the other schoolhouse up there where the church is now, you know.  And that schoolhouse wasn’t big enough, and they needed more room.  And they built this other one.  And I don’t know how that house caught afire and burnt up everything.  They lost everything!  I don’t think there was anybody at home when it happened.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: They came home to a pile of ashes?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  They lost everything.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What did they do?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: There wasn’t nothing they could do.  Started up again.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You know--who did they turn to?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t know where they went and stayed.  I know they went up there where—and lived in Nettie’s house right there below Doris’s, you know; where Marlene’s trailer is now.  I guess that must be where they moved to, because I know they stayed there during—while Samuel was in the service they lived there.  I don’t know what all—they lived there a good while, I know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So that was the end of the old schoolhouse?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That was the end of the old schoolhouse.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What was the end of the church?  Now, that Mormon Church was there from when you were a little girl until when?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Up until they, well, they built another one, you know where.  Louise’s house is setting on the very foundation of the old church.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Not the real old one; the old one was there, too.  They pushed the old church—that’s the one that you’re seeing now—pushed it across the road, and Leroy Blue lived in that house for a long time, until he moved up here where he is now.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh!  They turned it into a house.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They turned it into a house.  And Leroy lived in it, and—I don’t know what ever happened to that church.  I think they finally tore it down.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I imagine Sam Blue did, because he was the one that had access to all that, you know.  And—But anyway, after they moved out, they went across the road and built a new church there on the foundation where Louise got that house.  And they had classrooms built in there beside the big main auditorium.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, so—year?  When did this all happen?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t remember the year they built that new part.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, Leroy would have been married.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh yes, he was married.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He was married to May by the time they lived in there.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And they built that church across the road.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Then they built the one that they have now.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Then they built that one later, after they built this one up here.  And that must have been in the 60s some time.  Must be the 60s.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: After the federal government took over.  And then they tore the other one down?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And then Louise—Did Louise build that house?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, her and her husband.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Bryson.  They built it.  Didn’t Sally Beck’s house burn down?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I guess, sometime or another, maybe.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But you don’t remember seeing any of those?  Do you remember any forest fires?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, yes!  They used to have forest fires down there a lot!  And I remember different ones would run out and fight fires, and a lot of times they’d have fires and somebody would set it for the fun of it, I thought!  A lot of times people would burn a lot, but where we lived, I know we never did have any fires over there much.  We always kept fires out of there because, like I said, it wasn’t too thickly settled back over where we lived.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We were kind of off to ourselves, you know, and a lot of people—we just stayed over there and we kept the fires out.  That’s why there’s a lot of big timber in there.  Of course now, some people—somebody—might have been in there and cut some of it; but there was a lot of big wood in there because we kept the fires out.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Tell me about the square dances.  I don’t know how we lost that stuff.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: The square dances?  Well, we used to have them on Saturday night; every Saturday night somebody would say, “Let’s have a square dance!”  And we’d go to whoever’s house, you know, would say that they could have it.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Who usually had them?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I remember my brother-in-law he loved to dance!  And he used to have them at his house.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Raymond?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, Irvin.  Irvin Gordon used to have them.  And I remember, I don’t know who lived there—might have been Douglas’s daddy, I don’t know—but it was across on the Kelley Farm.  We used to go over there because there was Indians living over there on that farm, you know.  That’s right across from where I lived, you know.  The branch just divides Kelly farm from where I lived.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And we used to go over there.  But I don’t know if that was Douglas’s house or Willie Sanders.  Different ones lived over there, and they’d, you know, make room.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What, did they clean the room out?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  They had a big room and they’d move everything out, except, you know, where somebody could sit down—put chairs around the walls.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And who provided the music?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Charlie Crawford.  A big old black man—a nigger.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And he’d play a—what?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he played the guitar.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: The guitar.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: The guitar, yes.  And that’s what he played when we had a dance by it.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But he did the calling?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  Some of the Indians did that—the calling—and then I know we used to have—I don’t know who lived up there.  And right there below Doris’s in that, in the—where Roy’s mama lived!  We used to go there and have dances there.  I don’t know—Aunt Wysie, I guess, must have let them have dances in there.  Or Roy.  Or maybe John, when John Brown—maybe.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But I’ve danced there a lot of times, at that house.  And Billy asked me one time, “Grandma, did you have any white beaux to come out here?”  And I said, “Yes, there used to be some from up around the river bend used to come around here.”  And [he said], “Well, did you dance with them?”  And I said, “I danced with some.”  And there was—I forget their names.  There used to be three of them used to come down here and dance, you know.  And I remember that one place where they danced.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, did you know many white people, except people married into the tribe?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, not too many.  A few, but not a lot—just those that would come in, you know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Who was your best friend?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Who was my best friend?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We were all good friends as far as I know! [Laugh]  Well, I always figured—me and Lula and Doris and Jeanette, we were all about the same age, and we kind of, you know, chummed around together.  Those are the ones that I was really close to.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Those four?  What would you do?  Where would you go?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, just went to dances.  We’d—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You’d go together?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  Up to church.  Something like that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: A boy didn’t take you to the dance?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No!  We met up there, and that’s how we got to be with them, you know.  They’d all meet there, and that’s how we’d meet them.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Were you allowed to date?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, we didn’t go out dating.  We didn’t go without a chaperone.  That’s one thing we didn’t do.  Not like people do now.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Your mother allowed you to go to the dances, but she wouldn’t let you go anywhere else?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, she was always along.  She would go to the dances, too.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, she went with you?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, for heaven’s sakes!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, they were right there.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So everybody went?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Everybody went to the dances.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did your mama dance?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, she danced some; I remember that.  Everybody took part, you know—the young and the old.  Of course, I was telling you about that old man dancing, that old man Davis Ayers.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes!  Tell me about that again.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He was dancing with the young girls—he always wanted a young partner to dance with!  And all the young girls always tried to get away from him if they could because he was too old to swing, you know.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he’d stand in one place and pull you and let you do the swinging.  And everybody had to fight, you know, to stay on their feet!  Nobody wanted to dance with him!  But all our parents used to tell us, “Now, don’t hurt Davis’s feelings.  Dance with him if he asks you.”  He didn’t have a partner, you know, and if he got to us before our partners come in, we would dance a little bit with him to keep from hurting his feelings.  Because he really loved to dance!  And I guess he was way up in his sixties or seventies, I guess.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And he did something about that time?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes!  He turned the time back one night, my husband said.  That was before me and my husband got married.  He told Douglas.  Everybody quit at 12 o’clock, you know.  They wouldn’t go over and dance on Sunday morning.  And he was having such a good time that night he said, “Oh,” he said, “Let’s turn the clock back!”  And he had his pocket watch—he had his watch—and they turned it back an hour!  And they danced on Sunday morning!  And my husband said that was the truth.  He said, “I know it.”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, what would people say if they found out about that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: There was nothing they could say!  It done happened and done over with.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did you do anything on Sunday?  What did you do on—Describe a Sunday.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Just go to church and that’s all.  Go to church and come back and lay around the rest of the day.  Read anything you wanted to, do like that.  Or go visiting, if you wanted to.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But you didn’t make pots?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, we didn’t.  That’s something—we never did do things like that on Sunday.  I know my mother always told us that was the Lord’s Day, and we were supposed to respect it and go to church.  And you didn’t go off.  We didn’t even go fishing!  People fish now on Sundays and everything!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, you didn’t even fish?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh no!  We didn’t fish.  I remember my husband going fishing, and I used to tell him!  And Landrum George used to put a trout line across, you know, the river.  Trout lines they did.  And catch the fish.  And they baited on Saturday and then they’d go on.  They wouldn’t bait on Sunday.  And they’d go down and look there.  And I said, “You oughtn’t do that—it’s Sunday!”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And they’d say, “Well, we’re not doing anything!”  And I said, “Well, one of these days you’re going to—you’ll catch the devil down there!”  So they went down one Sunday, and, ah, and my husband said they caught—they didn’t catch it; the fish got away.  He said it was the longest fish he ever seen!  And my husband was long and got long legs!  And he said, “That thing was long as from my hip clear down to my foot!”  And he said, “All I seen was part of his backbone up and the end of his tail; and I didn’t see his head because,” he said, “when I got it to the boat, when I raised up the line,” he said, “that fish took a nose dive!”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he said it took him and the boat up the river!  And he said he just saw the length of his back as he went along and the end of his tail.  And he said that was as long as his leg!  And he said that was the biggest fish!  And he said, “I wonder how big it would have been if he had been out of the water?”  But I told him, I said, “Well that was the devil you all caught!”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Because he was doing it on Sunday?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah! [Laughter]  And Landrum laughed about it, and he said he told Douglas afterwards, he said, “Well, she’s been telling us we were going to catch the devil; I guess that was him!”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yesterday you mentioned that the winter before, just before you went to West Virginia was a hard winter.  Describe that whole situation.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I think that was back in, let’s see—I went in ’25, I believe.  Yes, that was the year.  I don’t know why that was kind of rough.  There wasn’t jobs or nothing, you know; no work, and nobody could get no jobs or anything.  And I got this—I don’t know whether Jesse was working; I believe he was out of work, far as I can remember.  He didn’t have no job at that time.  And I remember I went to work in West Virginia and I sent home money, you know, to my mother when I got paid.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You sent your money home?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, I sent it home.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: All of it?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: About half of it.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: About half of it home.  Because Jesse wasn’t working?  And how about Furman?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, Furman was little.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Too little?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, he was just a little fellow, about twelve or thirteen years old.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So that was really the only opportunity for the family to make money that year?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I don’t know.  We still, you know—she still had a lot of canned stuff and like that.  But, you know, money—money-wise—you know, yes, money-wise, like that—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Didn’t have any?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: There wasn’t a lot of money then.  Nobody had no money. [Laughs]  Everybody was in that boat, and they didn’t have any money to spare!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So you really took up the slack then?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: When you did that—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And you stayed up there for a year?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I didn’t stay quite a year.  I got homesick and wanted to come home, and I came home.  And I came home along about—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Do you remember the train ride?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  I caught the train—well, I had ridden the train all my life.  I used to ride back and forth to Cherokee.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Tell me about that.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I used to get on the train and ride to Cherokee, you know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Right here in Rock Hill?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, how did you go about it?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, they’d bring me up here to the train station and buy me a ticket, and I’d get the ticket and ride on the train.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did you have to go straight?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We changed, I believe, in Asheville; one time these, I think, changed in Asheville, and got on another one to go to Cherokee.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did you carry a lunch, or—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, I don’t remember carrying a lunch!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Was it exciting, or—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I had gotten used to it, so it didn’t—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You did it so often?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How many times would you get home when you were up there at school?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, I’d get home every summer, you know; when it was vacation time, I always come home.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How about Christmas?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, I couldn’t come home because I wouldn’t have, you know, a long holiday.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh.  Well, what kind of Christmas did you have at Cherokee?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I just stayed at school.  But I used to go down to Lottie Jenkins’s; she always, she said, “If they’ll let you, come to my house and spend Christmas with me.”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Of course, she knew we were Catawbas, you know; and I remember one time, Doris was up there—she and I went down to Lottie Jenkins’s, and she was good to us at Christmas!  She’d get us to come down there and spend Christmas, and we’d stay a week with her and we’d go back.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What would you do at Christmas?  What kind of Christmas would she give you?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We’d have a big—she’d have a—you know, cook a big meal, you know, for Christmas.  And we’d stay down there and we’d help her, you know, while we were there.  We was just like at home, you know?  She’d tell us to just help her around the house, help her wash dishes, you know, and do things like that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did she have a tree?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, she had a tree; she always had a tree in her living room.  Of course, she hardly ever used her living room anyway, but—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That was just for formal?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Just for looks, yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did you have presents, or did they come from home?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, sometimes my mama, she usually would send me something, you know.  But I don’t know whether Lottie gave us anything or not.  Maybe some little thing, you know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, people didn’t give too many presents then, did they?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, not too much.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It wasn’t like today, where it is—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: --where people spend thousands of dollars.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, we didn’t expect too much.  I think, you know, people expect too much.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes, they do.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I think if you can give something, I think that ought to be—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That’s enough.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That’s enough.  But they give a lot.  Of course, I know—my kids, this year, they give me a lot of things.  But I appreciated it.  But still, I always—I have always give them something, because they told me not to even buy them anything.  But I told them I didn’t think it would be Christmas if I couldn’t give—I said, “It won’t be much, but it will be something.”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: “It won’t be a lot.”  Well, Floyd said, “Well, mama, I’d just rather that you get things for yourself,” he said, “and spend it for something you need.”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes.  Well, do you think Christmas has suffered because we spend so much money?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I don’t know if it’s suffered or not, but I think it’s too commercialized. [Laughs]

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It’s hard to tell that it’s Christ’s birthday.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That’s right.  They leave Christ out, and they think more of the other things, you know?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Right, right. Yes.  And that’s, ah—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They just think that’s a day of getting, and, you know—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Just to get things.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Just things and more things.  Can you tell me more about Roy Brown driving that car?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, I know he used to drive that car and blow that horn when he’d go through the reservation!  And everybody would say, “Well, John Brown’s in town!”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Tell me about October Harris.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: What is to tell about October Harris?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She had a slew of children.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, she didn’t have but one.  Alfred Harris, Peggy’s husband.  That’s the only child she had.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh.  I’m thinking of somebody else, I guess.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You must be, because she didn’t have but one child.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Just that one?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Just that one.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I see.  Isn’t there a story about her with a dog or something?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Putting her fist in a dog’s mouth?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That was an old Indian, way back!  Lula was the one told you that.  You said—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: No, I thought—maybe Doris told me.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Lula was the one told you!  You told me about it.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Sticking her fist—the beehive—she got a bee swarm or something in her dress.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That must be Doris that told me about that.  What was the first—can you tell me about the first load of pottery you sold?  That was just part of—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.  That was just part of living, I guess. [Laugh]

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh.  That railroad bridge—when you went across that railroad bridge could you see the water underneath?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Why, yes.  You know—sure.  We had to walk all between—all we had to walk on—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You walked on the ties.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  You walked on the crossties.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Weren’t you afraid you’d fall through?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t know why I wasn’t afraid.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Of course, your grandmother had you by the hand.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We was walking down that—no, not all the time she didn’t.  I walked them things just like she did!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Could you swim?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Couldn’t swim a lick, and can’t swim yet!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So you all never went down to swim in the river?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I went in the river some, but never did learn to swim in it.  Now, all the boys—every boy—learned to swim in the river.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: No!  But the girls didn’t?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, they didn’t go down there too much. I always wished I had learned to swim, but I didn’t.  Of course, I think everybody should know how, because you never know what might happen.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So, if you had fallen in that river, that would have been the end?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh yes, that would have been the end of me!  I used to play in it, though, close to the bank.  I didn’t venture out too far!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How high is that bridge from the water?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, way up!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Way up there?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, it’s on up there.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, my goodness!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I bet I couldn’t walk one now!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Because I was younger then.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Tell me about your little girlfriend who died in the influenza.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, let’s see—Jenny.  She was a Saunook, and she was a little cripple girl.  I remember she was a clubfoot and she was in my—she was a classmate.  She was in the same class.  And she just died.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Is she the one who shook the stool?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t know who shook the stool; I never did know who it was.  I just said it must have been someone visiting me that had died, you know, because quite a few of them had died.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did you room with her?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, we had one great big dormitory, and a crowd of us slept there; but she slept in the bed next to me.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: This little Jenny Saunook?  Did they speak Cherokee, those children?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh yeah, those children—they knew Cherokee.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did they get punished for doing it?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So, they jabbered in it all the time?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, to one another that could talk.  They talked Cherokee a good bit.  But now, when they went to school, they talked English, you see.  I know while I was there, there was some kids that came that couldn’t even speak English.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: At all?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You know they sent them when they were six years old, and I knew several of them couldn’t speak a bit of English.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did they have trouble with them being homesick and crying and carrying on?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, some.  But, you know, they weren’t too bad, I didn’t think.  They done right good, them being little fellas like that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Was the food good?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, they had good food!  The government fed them.  It was good, substantial food is what it was.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Good diet.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So you didn’t miss mama’s cooking?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, you didn’t miss that.  We got plenty of beans and potatoes, and, of course, on Sundays, she always fixed pie or, you know, something extra, on Sunday.  Something extra.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And did you take church together?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, that had a—yes, they had an auditorium.  We’d go to the auditorium for church services.  You see, you didn’t go out to the churches; you just went to the auditorium.  They had somebody to speak—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Of course, everybody up there is a Baptist.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Just about.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Almost.  There is some Mormons though, now.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, they got a Mormon church up there now.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Right.  There are some Mormons.  Who was Gertrude Watts?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That’s Jim Watts’s wife.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: The young wife?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: The one I told you married Jim Watts.  She was younger than he was.  He was an old man when he married her, and he had those two children, Jimmy and William Watts.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So he was married the first time to the Indian, and she died; and then he married Gertrude?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Where did he find her?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Here in Rock Hill.  He was working up here in the mill, and he met her.  But her mother was married to Davis Ayers, Gertrude’s mother was.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And who was she?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, I don’t know; they called her ‘Old Lady Dye’.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: ‘Old Lady’ who?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Old Lady Dye.  She was a Dye before she married Davis Ayers.  And I remember, when I was a kid, everybody said ‘Old Lady Dye’, and that’s all I ever knew.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That woman went by her name, but—I think her name was Mary Dye.  She, she was a Dye before she married Davis, but that’s what everybody called her when they were talking about her: “That’s Old Lady Dye.”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And Gertrude was her little girl?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That was her daughter, yes, by a previous marriage.  You know, she had two girls, I think; one named Fannie Dye, and Gertrude.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And Fannie married outside of the—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, she—Fannie married somebody; I believe she married a Fagan.  No, Gertrude married a Fagan.  And she had some children by a Fagan, but I think she gave them away somewhere along the way.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So she never brought those with her?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She had them down there for a while.  I remember seeing them when they were right little; but after they got up older, I think she must have given them away to somebody.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes.  What eventually happened to her?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Who, Gertrude?  The last time I heard tell of it, they sent her to Columbia to the mental place.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, really?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  She went there when Jimmy and—now, they say what caused it, they said she had pellagra and that’s what caused her to lose her mind.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, really?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That’s what I was told now.  That’s all I know.  And she went down there, and they said she died down there.  And William has tried to find her, but he can’t find—I don’t think.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: The last I heard, they said he didn’t find any record of where she had died down there.  But she died there.  But they didn’t have no record when he tried to find her.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Isn’t that funny.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes, they should have a record of that.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That’s right.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Of course, now, maybe he didn’t know how to look.  Although he should from the Mormon Church.  They would tell him how to do that.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, Jimmy—well, William was a smart little fella.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: There was nothing crazy about Jimmy.  He knew what was going on.  William was smart, and Jimmy is, too.  They never could get no details on her because she went down there—Jimmy was very small; I don’t think he was over three or four years old from what I remember.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, so she never raised them?  So who raised those children then?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, Leola Blue kept Jimmy for a long time, I know; and then she kept William.  Lucy kept Jimmy.  Lucy Starnes raised Jimmy, and see, Jim Starnes is Lucy’s uncle, I believe.  Or his aunt.  I don’t know how it goes.  But anyway, they were related there.  But she raised Jimmy, and Nelson and Leola kept William and raised him.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What about Clifford?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That’s the one I call Jimmy.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh!  You call Clifford ‘Jimmy’?  He was—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: His name was James Clifford, I think, and we always called him Jimmy.  But his name was Clifford.  And Lucy and her husband raised Jimmy.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So the father—of course, he was old.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  He had a heart attack when the children, I guess along when they were living down there.  He was chasing a cow one day and he run the old cow around and around.  He was living with Nelson and Leola, you see.  Leola was—he raised her, you see.  And he was running the old cow and he never did come home.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, that was before Gertrude died.  And Gertrude found him—that’s his wife—found him.  Gertrude, she said she saw him when he come up the hill and she went over there to look.  And when she come down there, she found him lying on the ground, and he was dead.  And they said she hollered just as loud as she could holler!  And I think Leola heard her and she ran over there and found Gertrude with him.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Then she went insane afterwards?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, after that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: After that.  And then they took her to Columbia, and she just never came back?  So Leola took one boy, and Lucy Starnes took the other?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: An awful lot of children without parents.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Of course, people had to stick together.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, yes!  It was the only way.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: There was not—the state did nothing.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.  People took care of one another, you know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I wonder if that wasn’t better.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It might be.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Of course, there was a lot of suffering—financial.  But I wonder what’s worse?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t know.  You wonder sometimes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes.  Whether the children were better off being taken in, or if they’d be better off with social security.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: There wasn’t no social security money back then; it wasn’t heard of then.  And if you took a child in, you’d have to raise him on your own.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It was your project.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  That was your project if you took him in.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Sure.  Tell me about your little boy with his ax.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Who?  About Dewey?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes sir.  Well, I took him to town one time, and he saw an ax up there.  And he wasn’t but five years old.  And he cried and cried!  He saw that little ax.  I think, as far as I can remember, I think it was about a two-and-a-half pound ax.  It was a small ax.  He wanted that ax so bad, and we brought him out of that store.  He cried!  My husband got tired of hearing him cry, and he said, “Come over here, boy” and took him on back in there and bought that ax!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he came home and he chopped wood until he made himself sick!  He chopped wood all evening, and, you know, that rascal never did cut hisself or nothing with that ax!  Never did.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Never did cut himself?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Never did cut himself.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, it was Nola who got chopped with—one of her children got chopped with the ax.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Might have.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes, she was telling me last time.  But he just loved that ax?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He loved that ax.  He loved to cut wood.  He’d get out there and cut wood!  There was a Cherokee came down here and stayed with me and my husband.  Ben Powell.  You might have heard of him.  But anyway—I think he had a wife, and they had separated; and she was suing him for support.  And he come down to the Indian reservation to the Catawbas to stay so the law couldn’t touch him as long as he was out of state.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We didn’t know it until one time the police came down there and got him out of my house one night, and we didn’t know what was wrong.  We didn’t know; we just thought he was visiting!  But I had knew Ben when I was at Cherokee.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: At school?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, but he was a lot older than I am.  But I knew he married a—but I knew his children and I knew his sisters, and so Ben just stayed with us for a while.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he was out there and he cut—Ben was good to get wood.  He’d keep all the wood for my husband, because, you see, my husband was working.  And he just hauled up loads of wood and he cut big wood.  And when he cut the wood off like this in chunks, you know, Dewey would take his little ax and split them in half!  And that’s what he did.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh really!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  And he could do it!  And he wasn’t but five years old.  And he just cut!  And he got—what he done, he cut so long he sweated and took a cold.  Got cold—cooled off and got cold, and then he couldn’t use his little ax for a day or two.  He was sick; I had to keep him in the house.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I never will forget that! [Laugh]

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, what ever happened to Ben Powell, then?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, he stayed until the police come and got him and took him back to Cherokee.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And he never came back any more?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh yes, he came back after that again, and he stayed around a while.  He was a good old fellow, though.  He would drink, but he wasn’t, you know, mean or nothing like that.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And I never did see him just, you know, passed out or nothing.  But he drank; I remember that.  That’s all I hated about him when he come.  I remember one time I was sick—oh, and I had, I had a cyst on my hip here and I had to go to the doctor to have that taken off.  And the doctor told me—he didn’t put me to sleep; he just froze it to where I could stand it and then he took it out.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he told me he took out about two pounds of meat!  And I guess he did, because he left a hole in my leg when he took it out!  But he said, “I wanted to be sure I took it all so it wouldn’t come back and, you know, give you trouble.”  And he took a big piece of meat out of my leg and he let me come home.  And he said, “I think you can go home.”  He said, “But you stay off of it.  Stay in the bed.”  And, ah, he said, “Stay off of it!”  So he let me come home.  I think I spent one night, and then the next day he let me come home.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And then he said, “You come back and see [me] every so often, and I’ll take the stitches out,” you know.  So I came home, and Douglas asked his sister Reola—that was Reola; she wasn’t married, and Ben got kind of sweet on Reola.  And he liked Reola.  So he asked Reola to come and cook for me, you know, while I was, while I was just—and I never will forget Ben.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He said, “Oh, I’ll help; I’ll help her!” he said.  And I remember we had killed, you know, hogs that year, and we had great big old hams; and he said, “I can cut the meat and cook the meat, and” he said, “while she fixes the other stuff,” you know.  She lived out there with Nola, and she come out there every morning and fixed breakfast, and—oh, he liked Reola!  But Reola was too young for him, you know; Reola was just a young girl then.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he was crazy about Reola!  He would have married Reola, if he could have got Reola to.  But Reola wouldn’t; she didn’t like him.  But I told Douglas, I said, “I never eat such big slices of ham but when I was sick!” I said.  Ben Powell and—I think we had big old hams; and he’d cut a slice, and I think they’d be this big around!  And he’d cut, he’d cut one for everybody—a slice like that—and, you know, if that had been me, I would have cut them in half, too; but he was slicing the whole ham! [Laugh]

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Trying to impress Reola?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But I told Douglas, “Shucks, I eat ham!”  And he said Ben Powell liked that ham, too.  But it was good ham, too.  You see, we had raised it and cured it ourselves, you see.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, how did he cure the ham?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: With salt.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did you have a room that you put it in or something?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You had a little—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  We had a great big old table in there, and we’d salt all that meat down, you know.  And you’d salt it down where it would—you can—and all that, it would run, you know, and it would dry out.  You see, the salt would draw all that water out—all everything out; then, when it got dry, we’d sack them up and then hang them up.  And they’d be all right.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: They wouldn’t spoil or anything?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.  You see, you’d have it—then after you’d get all that water out, and blood was drawed out of it.  And, you see, there wasn’t no way—that meat was good meat.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did it ever spoil on you?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We might have lost some if we had too many to carry over into the next—way over into the spring of the next year.  It would get rank on you, you know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And what—you’d just have to throw it away?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  We’d just have to throw it away, [or] use it—cut it up and make soap out of it, or—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How do you do that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You never did know of people making soap?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You use lye to make soap.  You render all that fat off of your meat, you know, and get the grease and boil that, and get your fat strained out and cleaned.  And then you put you a can of lye in there, and it will, it will just—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Bubble up?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And you’d pour it in a mold or whatever you got, and—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It would be bricks?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Or you would put it in that great big thing and cut it.  And it would—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Like fudge?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: In the shape of a how big soap bar you want.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, for heaven’s sakes!  And you made soap every year?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, we did make it, and some—I didn’t make it every year.  But if we had a lot of stuff like that to throw away, we used it, you see.  We made use of it.  Didn’t waste it.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You didn’t throw anything away?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.  You could use it, you see.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And how did you make lard?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You took all the trimming off the hog and then lopped some off of the fatback, you know—this great big old streak of—and you’d even trim the entrails, you know.  So much fat off of the—you’d trim that and take all of that and cut it up and put it in a big pot.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And you just put so much water there and boil it, and leave it in there and it will just boil.  And after a while, everything just turns to grease; and all that fat will come to the top, and, see, it will get right crisp and come to the top.  And [you] just skim all that off and strain your lard and put it in your cans, and you’ve got good lard.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And it won’t spoil?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, if you keep it a long time.  If you didn’t keep it over the—you see, we didn’t have no refrigerator or nothing.  And we would have enough to do us for one—through the winter.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How many hogs did you kill?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, sometimes we’d kill two or three.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And that would give you enough lard?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, how did you manage without refrigeration?  When did you get your first refrigerator?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t remember when I—you know, the first one we owned, we had [to] put your ice in there, and kept it in there, you know.  You didn’t have no electric.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Was that down on the reservation?  You had an iceman come down there?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, they’d bring ice down there.  I was always thinking about that.  That’s right funny.  If they run out of ice, you know, they’d always come back from town with ice to fill your refrigerators sometime.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But they had a lot of colored people on them routes, you know, and you couldn’t get a colored man to hit that reservation after dark!  He wouldn’t come back.  He’d say, “I’ll bring you some ice back,” and you wouldn’t see him.  You’d have to wait until the next day.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, really?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They didn’t come back if they had to come in there at night; they wouldn’t come back.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Why?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They were afraid to.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did they have a reason?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, they didn’t have a reason; they just had about—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: They just didn’t want to come down there.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They thought the Indians—after dark—would do something to them.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Isn’t that funny.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Just an idea that they had.  But it was, you know, comical to think about it, you know?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But it was—the Catawbas didn’t associate with the blacks at all.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, they have never been a person to do that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So far, you’ve only talked about the man with the music, making the music; and then the man cooking that fish stew.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: The fish stew?  Yes, that’s the onliest thing.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Is that the only colored people that would come down there?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, that’s the only ones.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: There was no other contact?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.  Only one.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What about if they worked on a farm?  They might—did you know black people?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I knew the Parkers that lived over there on that farm from us, but that’s the onliest one.  And then I remember the Crawford family.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I knew them; I knew his mother-in-law.  She was a Steele.  And Charlie Crawford, he married a—and Charlie Crawford married, well, he married a Parker, Charlie did.  So I knew him.  And then there was a Steele lived up there, right—she lived there.  And I knew her and her husband for a long time.  And she was a midwife.  And she used to come down and help deliver children, sometimes, on the reservation.  And I remember her by that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She delivered Indian children?  None of the Catawba women did that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, not too much.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Who delivered you?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Dr. Hills.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And Jesse and Furman?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, Furman was—I, I believe she helped my mama.  I believe she delivered Furman, because she was with my mother when Furman was born.  I don’t think she delivered him; she was just there when Furman—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did she come to your house to work?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, she just come down there and stayed with her until Furman was born, that’s all.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Because she was really alone.  You were tiny, and—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, we were all small then, and my grandmother would come up and help her.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes, but your grandmother was never [a] midwife.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.  She went around and had been with a lot of women when they had children—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Who was this colored woman?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She was a Steele.  Let’s see; I think her name was Nancy Steele.  I think.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh.  This refrigeration—what did you do before you had an icebox?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, we just done without.  Used the spring, like I told you.  Spring water, where it was running—that’s what we used for our milk and our butter, anything like that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Of course, if you killed a chicken, you ate it right up.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, yes.  You couldn’t save anything like that.  We cooked and ate it.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did you ever have beef?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Occasionally we had beef.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Very seldom, or--?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  Unless somebody killed one.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But then it would have to be—you can’t cure beef, can you?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You’d have to eat it right up.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You have to give it out to your friends and neighbors, you know?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That would be a problem.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It wouldn’t be no problem to get rid of it! [Laughs.]

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: No.  But I mean it would be valuable meat.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Where you—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But back then they didn’t consider meat or nothing like that valuable like you do now.  It wasn’t no value; you just ate it.  You see, people raised everything they had then, and people didn’t have to do—you know, all that money they didn’t spend providing stuff.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What did you do with the hide?  What did you do with the hide from the hog?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: From the hog?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes.  The skin.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You ain’t got no hide when you take all the hair off it.  You scald them like you do a chicken, you know, when you took the hair off.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: There’s no—the skin wasn’t valuable?  You couldn’t do anything with the skin?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: There ain’t nothing but hair when you get it off.  It’s hair.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes, I see.  How do you make souse meat?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, you make that with a fat meat, you know.  Cook it and stir it, and put your red pepper and sage—whatever you want—in it. And when it gets cold, it will just freeze itself; and you can just cut a block off and it would be solid.  But, you know, it couldn’t last too long either.  You couldn’t make too much of that to keep, you know, then.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It wouldn’t last?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It wouldn’t last too long.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And it would spoil.  Did you ever eat chitlins?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, that’s something that I never did fool with.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did anybody cook that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, a lot of people did.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: A lot of the Indians did?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, there were some of the older Indians fooled with it.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Who would cook it?  [It] just smells so nasty!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But not me!  I couldn’t smell it and I never did eat it!  I never did eat none!  I can’t even eat tripe, and, you know, tripe is a beef stomach.  And I can’t eat tripe.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I never tried it, but I—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: My husband and my brother, Jesse, used to eat it, but I know—but I could never eat it!  I’d cooked it for them, and it would be just as pretty as you ever seen.  But I—it would be the prettiest thing you ever looked at—never could eat it.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You just couldn’t do it?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I guess it’s just not my—you know, a lot of times you get an idea about something, you know, and it just takes away your appetite.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes, right.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Just like people eating frog legs now.  Never could eat frog legs.  And my kids used to hunt them—that’s Floyd and Dewey.  Floyd used to get a slingshot and get the legs.  And he’d say, “Mama, it eats better than chicken!”  “No,” I said one thing.  “When I see them little frog legs hopping around in the pan,” I said, “I just can’t go to it!”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: [Laugh.]

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And I can’t! [Laugh.]  You know, you buy them in restaurants and everywhere!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes.  They are expensive!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I know it!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did Douglas Harris hunt?
